emergencyCard.title: Dog Emergency Card
emergencyCard.subtitle: Essential emergency contacts, poisoning symptoms, and first aid steps. Print this card and keep it handy.
emergencyCard.poisonNote: Available 24/7. A consultation fee may apply.
emergencyCard.firstAid_step1: Stay calm. Remove your dog from the source of danger.
emergencyCard.firstAid_step2: Call ASPCA Poison Control (888) 426-4435 or your emergency vet immediately.
emergencyCard.firstAid_step3: Do NOT induce vomiting unless directed by a professional.
emergencyCard.firstAid_step4: Note what your dog ate, how much, and when. Bring packaging if possible.
emergencyCard.firstAid_step5: Transport to the nearest 24-hour emergency vet as quickly as possible.

hikingChecklist.title: Dog Hiking Checklist
hikingChecklist.subtitle: Everything you need to pack for a safe and fun hike with your dog.
hikingChecklist.item_extra_water: Extra water (1 oz per lb per hour of hiking)
hikingChecklist.item_harness: Harness or collar with ID tags
hikingChecklist.item_id_tags: Updated ID tags and microchip info
hikingChecklist.item_paw_balm: Paw balm or wax for rough terrain
hikingChecklist.item_booties: Dog booties for hot pavement or rough trails
hikingChecklist.tip1: Check the trail's leash policy before you go — some trails require leashes at all times.
hikingChecklist.tip2: Start with short hikes and gradually increase distance for puppies and senior dogs.
hikingChecklist.tip3: Avoid hiking during peak heat (10am-4pm in summer). Touch the pavement — if it's too hot for your hand, it's too hot for paws.
hikingChecklist.tip4: Always yield to other hikers and keep your dog close on narrow trails.

seasonal.spring_tip: Wildflower season is in full bloom. Watch for foxtails on trails — they can be dangerous for dogs. Check flea & tick prevention.
seasonal.summer_tip: Avoid hiking 10am-4pm — hot pavement burns paws! Stick to beaches and shaded trails. Always bring extra water.
seasonal.fall_tip: Perfect hiking weather! Check out foliage trails and dog-friendly pumpkin patches. Daylight getting shorter — bring reflective gear.
seasonal.winter_tip: Rainy season means muddy trails. Bring towels and check trail closures before heading out. Indoor dog parks are great alternatives.
